//: A counselor from far away, Rhy can offer a lot of supports to player and survivors if she can get herself sorted a little

dynamic_line: What brings you around here?  We don't see a lot of new faces.

responses.text: Is there anything I can do to help you out?

yes: Good to see you're still around.
dynamic_line.no: Hi there.  I don't think we've met before.  I'm Rhyzaea, people call me Rhy.

responses.text: I'm afraid I can't talk right now.

dynamic_line: So, what's your story?  We don't see a lot of new people back here.

responses.text: Just a curious traveler.  What's up with you?

dynamic_line: I'm doing as well as can be expected, I suppose.  Nice of you to ask.

It's a long, long story.  I'm not from around here, I'm actually from way out in Western Canada. I'd always wanted to see New England, and I was down here on vacation when, well, you know.  I got evacuated, but because I'm not a US citizen they weren't willing to take me downstairs.  I can understand that, even if I don't like it much.  To tell you the truth I'm still coming to terms with the fact that I'll probably never know how my family and my band are doing.

I was a counselor actually, I worked for my band, Gitxsan.  Did a lot of mental health and addictions for people that had been through some really tough stuff.  Maybe not zombies eating your child level tough, but surprisingly not far off.  My people have gone through some real messy crap.

responses.text: What was it you were saying before?
Well, it's been nice talking to you, but I need to head out.

dynamic_line: My band is Gitxsan, we're from Northwestern British Columbia, around the Skeena River.  I'm from Hazelton, myself.  It's a beautiful place. I've been to Korea and Slovakia for the same reason.  I guess I'm a bit of a forest tourist?  I don't know if I'll ever see my own forest again, and the thought breaks my heart.

responses.text: What was it you were saying before?
Well, it's been nice talking to you, but I need to head out.

dynamic_line: My mom and dad are back in Hazelton, they live with my grandma and my older brother; he took a hard knock to the head doing dumb things as a kid, and he can't really take care of himself now.  I have a daughter, Angel, she's sixteen and didn't want to come with me on this trip.  God help me, I can't bear to think of her, she must think I'm dead.

dynamic_line: People up here are barely hanging on.  I've seen trauma before, a lot, but this is pretty much the worst imaginable.  Everyone has lost everything, with a huge dose of nightmare on top of it all.  We're putting on a brave face, but without help, things are going to break, really soon.
